All these steps were absolutely, completely necessary. And they also weren’t even close to enough. 

They were a downpayment on the action we have to take in the coming years – but I’m beyond excited to continue the fight next year with @JoeBiden & his team of climate all-stars.

And that wasn’t all. 

The bill also provided for roughly $35 billion total in clean energy R&D for other energy technologies, and extended clean energy tax provisions that we desperately need. https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/12/21/congress-climate-spending/

But there were other massively important energy provisions in yesterday’s bill. 

A proposal to reduce hydrofluorocarbons was included, which by itself will prevent half a degree Celsius of global warming. 

Hard to overstate what a big deal that is! https://twitter.com/RepCasten/status/1341390253249220609 QT @RepCasten HFCs are a potent class of greenhouse gases used in air conditioners and refrigerators. 

Our #COVIDagreement’s HFC provision will phase down HFCs 85% over 15 years—preventing half a degree Celsius in global warming. 

This is a BIG deal 👇🏼 https://twitter.com/brianschatz/status/1341193572448686087

2️⃣Our #FY21 package also includes my bill with @RepBillFoster directing $855 million to fund energy storage R&D and demonstration programs at DoE. 
 
Energy storage is vital to decarbonizing our electricity grid & I’m incredibly proud to see these two bills poised to become law. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep43MIlW4AEHQYI.jpg

Industrial emissions represented roughly 22% of all the GHG’s we pumped into the atmosphere last year. 

In order to get to net-zero emissions by 2050, we have to figure out a way to eliminate these emissions – this bill will help us develop the tech to do just that!

First, I want to highlight two bills I helped lead:

1️⃣ The Clean Industrial Technology Act authorizes $500 million in R&D funding to figure out how to decarbonize hard-to-decarbonize industries like steel or cement production. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep41m-sXMAMEzyc.jpg

This pandemic is a case study on why policymakers should always put science before politics. 

That’s why in addition to providing desperately needed #COVIDrelief, the #FY21 omnibus includes important provisions in our fight against the climate crisis! 

A not-so-brief 🧵

Proporciona $2 mil millones para @CISAgov, $267 millones por encima de la solicitud, para proteger a nuestra nación de los ataques cibernéticos.

Proporciona $21.67 billones para @fema: $17.1 billones para respuesta a desastres mayores y $3.32 billones para asistencia federal, incluyendo $130 millones para el Programa de Refugio y Alimentos de Emergencia de FEMA y $180 millones para seguridad sin fines de lucro.

Como en años pasados, la ley incluye $1.375MM para la "construcción de un sistema de barrera." La nueva administración podrá usar estos fondos para componentes del "sistema" que no sean barreras físicas. Al igual, se podrá proponer la rescisión y reapropiación de fondos.

La ley financia aumentos para cámaras corporales, alternativas de detención y estándares más altos de salud inicial. Protege a patrocinadores de niños no acompañados de detención/deportación y requiere que DHS preserve documentos/datos relacionados con la supuesta mala conducta.

La ley proporciona $20 millones para la Oficina del Defensor de Detención de Inmigración para investigar mala conducta/violaciones de derechos de personas bajo la custodia de ICE/CBP, y $190.2 millones para la Oficina del Inspector General para supervisión de detención de DHS.

Anoche, el Congreso aprobó la ley ómnibus del año fiscal 21, incluyendo fondos para @DHSGov. El proyecto de ley, por primera vez en años, recorta fondos para actividades de detención y deportación de ICE por $431 millones debajo de niveles del año anterior.

It provides $21.67B for @fema: $17.1B for major disaster response & $3.32B for fed. assistance, including $130M for FEMA's Emergency Food & Shelter Program & $180M for non-profit security. Provides $2B for @CISAgov, $267M above request, to protect our nation from cyber-attacks.

As in prior years, bill includes $1.375B for "construction of barrier system." New admin will have flexibility to use the funds for “system” components other than physical barriers. That funding can also be proposed for rescission & re-appropriation for better uses.

The bill funds increases for body worn cameras, detention case management alternatives, & higher initial health screening standards. It protects unaccompanied children sponsors from detention & removal by ICE & requires DHS to preserve docs & data related to alleged misconduct.

Bill allocates $20M for Office of Immigration Detention Ombudsman to investigate misconduct & violations of rights of individuals in ICE and CBP custody. It provides $190.2M for Office of Inspector General for increased oversight of DHS detention & immigration enforcement.

Last night, Congress passed the FY21 omnibus bill, including funding for @DHSGov. The bill cuts funding for ICE enforcement & removal activities by $431M - the first time in many years that this funding has been cut below prior year levels.

Their priorities are clear.

We need to act to avoid the disparities of a K-shaped downturn from damaging our economy for decades to come.

Investing in all of us is how we recover as a nation — more equitable and resilient than ever.

The House and Senate just passed a bill that won’t do enough to stop the devastation.

So Congress’s to-do list in the new year must include real relief. We must permanently upgrade the nation’s safety net so our economy isn’t held hostage by Republican inaction during a crisis.

After then-Senator Harris’s historic election in 2016 as the first woman of color to represent California, we now have another historic barrier shattered as Alex will be the first Latino to serve California in the United States Senate.
Today, our state gains yet another champion following a distinguished line of individuals who have shattered glass ceilings and hurdled obstacles in their way.
As our Secretary of State, Alex modernized our electoral process and led the effort to provide ballots by mail statewide so Californians could safely vote in this year’s election.

We served together in the State legislature where he passed landmark legislation to make California the first state in the nation to require chain restaurants to post calorie information directly on menus.

Anyways, that’s a very loose breakdown (at least process-wise) of how it went down.

Process is important because it’s how pols get overwhelmingly corrupt and unpopular things into legislation. They can’t campaign on it, so many use process & obscure deals to sneak things in.

The THIRD vote had the actual COVID relief: the too-little $600 checks, $300 in UI, SNAP⬆️,etc.

There were also some omnis tacked on, but less controversial. (I initially voted PRESENT on this bc this process is so F’d up, but then YES bc my families are so hungry. Wanted to 🤢)

The omnibus is actually a collection of legislation that funds each federal agency (Homeland Security $ + Enviro $ + NASA $, etc).

There are many agencies, so the 2nd vote was the omni w/ DHS, DoD, Fin Services & a lot of the “pork” leg people are objecting to (I also voted NO)

It’s gross but also true!

The dilemma many were dealing w/ was: bc these things were tied together, it made clean COVID relief impossible. You can largely thank Mitch for that. I’m not saying this is all 1 party but fr he’s awful.

Anyways the Omnibus has most of the gross stuff

2nd vote is the Omnibus.

What’s that? Basically the “deal” is centered on tying COVID relief to funding the gov(aka Omnibus).

They were tied together so pols who were against COVID relief (checks, SNAP, UI, etc) could trade for their horse write-offs etc in the Omni. Gross, no?

For context, it actually took 3 votes to pass this COVID bill. 

1st vote: The Rule (process vote)

The rule vote cleared the way for the bill to be brought to a vote so soon after text dropped.

It passed, which is one reason why the vote happened so fast. (I & others voted NO)

For people asking about the insane & corrupt tax giveaways in the deal (ex. the “3 martini lunch” trash 🚮) much of that gross stuff is actually the omnibus.

It’s a little confusing, but basically there’s 3 major components to the COVID deal:
1. Rule
2. Omnibus
3. COVID relief

#SmallBusiness owners are seeing the biggest hit from this pandemic. This bill allows for a "second draw" on PPP loans for the smallest of small businesses and expands eligibility to non-profits, restaurants and newspapers, and direct assistance to live entertainment venues.

Unemployment benefits have been extended thru mid-March 2021, and everyone is now eligible for 50 weeks of benefits (instead of 39) since the start of this pandemic. This bill provides $300 a week in benefits.

Americans need #survivalchecksnow. I am glad to see that the #COVIDrelief bill provided some funds for a second round of checks, but also expands direct payments to mixed-status households and is retroactive. Contrary to what the @senateGOP thinks, immigrants pay taxes.

Patients should NEVER have to pay for out-of-network surprise medical bills, especially during an emergency. It has NEVER been ok, and now, surprise medical billing is GONE. #peopleoverprofit #patientsfirst #COVIDrelief

Parents and families have struggled for MONTHS with little to no child care, on top of having to be essential workers or work from home with little help. The #COVIDrelief bill includes $10.25B to support child care providers & facilities with safety precautions and reopenings.

There are untold numbers of COVID-19 "long haulers," Americans who - on top of financial struggles - are still dealing with lung damage and brain fog. We need to understand the long-term effects of COVID-19 and there is funding in this bill to support that research. #COVIDrelief

The COVID relief bill includes $8.75B to support federal, state, local, territorial, and tribal public health agencies with distributing and tracking COVID-19 vaccines. That funding will help with mass storage & availability of vaccine doses in the coming months. #COVIDRelief

As the President-elect knows, Amtrak is a critical pillar of our national infrastructure. Congress approved $700 million for Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor last night. This will benefit millions of Americans.

Rhode Island’s colleges and universities are second to none. The research they do supports jobs and generates economic activity. Last night we approved nearly $130 million for the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCOR) so they can continue doing this work.

My Uncle Bud worked for 45 years at the Newport County Community Mental Health Center. These institutions are critical, especially right now. That’s why we fought to include $4 billion to support community health centers in the bill we passed last night. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep3OGuLXMAA1Ovs.jpg
We’ve never had a greater need for telehealth services than we do right now. I’m proud that last night Congress approved $250 million in new resources to support telehealth services.

Since LBJ created it more than a half century ago, Head Start has given millions of low-income kids access to early childhood education, health care, and nutrition services. The bill we passed last night includes nearly $11 billion to support this critical work.

The bill we passed last night includes $25 million for gun violence research at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. This is a good step. A lot more needs to be done to address gun violence, but I am confident we will make progress with @JoeBiden in the White House.

One of the highlights of my job (pre-COVID) has always been meeting with Special Olympians. I was thinking of Rhode Island Special Olympian LeeAnn Phillips (seen here with me a few years back) when we approved $23.7 million for the Special Olympics Education Programs last night. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep2baTWXcAItjZP.jpg

COVID-19 made it harder for refugees to apply for permanent residency. No one should be deported b/c of this pandemic.

That's why I'm pleased the House just approved a one-year extension of language I authored to allow Liberian refugees more time to apply for residency.

One of the greatest Rhode Islanders in history, Senator Claiborne Pell, established the Pell Grant program to ensure at-need students can pursue a degree. The bill we passed last night provides $22.5 billion in new resources for this important priority.

When kids have a safe place to go after school, they’re less likely to get in trouble or fall behind academically. That’s why I’m thrilled that we won the fight to include $1.3 billion for afterschool programming in last night’s spending bill.

When a veteran has a mental health crisis, they should be able to get help. That's why the bill we passed last night provides $115 million for the Veterans Crisis Line to provide 24/7 access to care. I was proud to help lead the fight for this funding on behalf of our veterans.

Last night, I was proud to support congressional passage of critical legislation to fully fund the government for FY 2021 & finally deliver desperately needed & long-awaited pandemic aid for the American people.

25/It also includes a total of $243.2 billion in both funding for VA, an increase of $25.3 billion above the fiscal year 2020 level. This funding will help provide for better care and increased access to care for our Veterans.

24/The agreement also extends and improves the Employee Retention Tax Credit to help workers during COVID-19 related closures or reduced wages and provides a tax break for employers offering paid-sick leave.

23/The Earned Income Tax Credit and the Child Tax Credit will be improved to ensure that families who faced unemployment or reduced wages during the pandemic are able to receive a strong tax credit based on their 2019 income.

22/…And $15 billion in dedicated funding for live venues, independent movie theaters, and cultural institutions and $20 billion for targeted EIDL Grants which are critical to many smaller businesses on Main Street.
21/There are also key modifications to PPP to serve the smallest businesses and struggling non-profits and better assist independent restaurants…
20/The agreement includes over $284 billion for first and second forgivable PPP loans, dedicates set-asides for very small businesses and lending through community-based lenders like CDFIs and MDIs.
19/The bill continues support for small businesses with critical funding and policy changes to help small businesses, including minority, women and veteran owned small businesses.
18/$300 per week in UI enhancement was included for Americans out of work and an 11-week extension for benefits was also included.

17/Included is another round of direct payments worth up to $600 per adult or child, not nearly enough to help all those struggling but a step in the right direction of getting relief directly to those who need it.

16/The funding will also implement a strong national testing and tracing strategy with billions reserved specifically for combating the disparities facing communities of color and to support our heroic health care workers and providers.
15/The package acknowledges that COVID-19 needs to be brought under control before we can start to see long-term economic stability by accelerating free and equitable vaccine distribution.
14/Fights for a more humane immigration approach, reducing funding for ICE’s overly aggressive detention and removal activities by $431 million below the fiscal year 2020 level.
13/The bill includes funding to tackle food insecurity, with robust investments in WIC, child nutrition programs, and SNAP to help ensure children and families have the nutrition they need.

12/It affirms our commitment to improving our environment with $9.24 billion, a $180 million increase, for the Environmental Protection Agency to ensure clean air and water and to hold polluters accountable.
11/…and $12.9 billion for IDEA Special Education Grants to States, an increase of $173 million above the FY 2020 enacted level.
10/The bill also supports better schools, with $16.5 billion for Education for the Disadvantaged Grants to Local Educational Agencies, an increase of $227 million above the FY 2020 enacted level…
9/$82 billion in funding would be provided for colleges and schools, including support for HVAC repair and replacement to mitigate virus transmission and reopen classrooms.

8/It expands access to housing, providing $43.4 million in new targeted vouchers to reduce homelessness among families with children, individuals, the unsheltered, veterans, and survivors of domestic violence.
7/There is $25 billion in critically needed rental assistance for families struggling to stay in their homes and an extension of the eviction moratorium.
6/I wanted to take some time to highlight provisions included in the COVID-19 relief section as well as programs that would be funded through the end of FY 2021:

4/I believe that at this point, our main priority should be getting aid, any aid, to families, health care workers, patients, and all those who need our help.

I’m proud to have worked with a bipartisan group of colleagues to help get this bill into shape and in the hands of House and Senate leaders. While I know that this bill is not perfect, I’m glad it will help American families weather this winter and get through the holidays.

For 9 long months, folks waited for Congress to deliver critical relief as they watched COVID-19 further devastate their communities. Today, despite that unacceptable delay, relief is officially on its way. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep2er7RXMAYaSma.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep2er7fXMAAeTsO.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep2er7QW4AANsmo.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep2er7RWMAUFNaN.jpg

This legislation fully funds the DOD through the fiscal year. Time and time again, we hear from our military leaders that the most critical thing they need is consistent, regular funding. This legislation will fully fund my NDAA, as well as all Oklahoma defense priorities.

The bill will also continue to make sure our hospitals, especially rural hospitals, and doctors, nurses and public health workers have what they need to keep fighting the coronavirus while also distributing the vaccine.
It will continue unemployment benefits and provide a new round of stimulus payments for households to help with immediate expenses.

In addition to continuing successful CARES Act programs, like the Paycheck Protection Program that already saved 625,102 jobs in Oklahoma, it will provide needed funds for vaccine distribution for all Americans.

After Senate Republicans have been working to pass additional COVID relief for months, I am pleased to announce we finally have responsible, bipartisan legislation that will provide direct and targeted coronavirus relief for families, hospitals and small businesses.
